1.34.text:
>>>TONY GUIDA: Hello. I'm
Tony Guida. This is my New York.

4.07.text:
We begin today with
two intimate very personal

8.31.text:
photos of a former mayor
of New York. Neither,

11.41.text:
I believe, has ever been seen

16.72.text:
of course but what is he

22.96.text:
Well, Mr. Mayor, what is that

26.09.text:
And who is that woman?
That woman is my guest.

57.46.text:
Let's look at it again. Mayor
John Lindsay in what looks like

61.09.text:
a very passionate moment.
The woman involved can

65.40.text:
now be revealed. She

68.80.text:
radio news in this town.
After illustrious career on

72.84.text:
WCBS 880 radio. It
is great to see you Irene.

78.18.text:
>>>IRENE CORNELL:
Great to see you Tony.

80.18.text:
>>>TONY GUIDA: That photograph,
I can't get over those two

82.18.text:
photographs. Tell me about
them. Where did that happen?

87.49.text:
>>>IRENE CORNELL: Well
first, those photos were so deep

89.59.text:
in my closet you're wouldn't
believe. They truly had never

93.46.text:
been seen except by few
members of my family.

95.96.text:
This happened on John Lindsay's
last day in office as mayor

101.13.text:
of New York City.
Now I had covered him for years;

105.31.text:
at city hall, when he ran for
president, went to Wyoming

110.21.text:
and Florida where he got chased
out by former residents of

113.55.text:
Queens who still remember the
snowstorm, so, but Lindsey

115.85.text:
was such a distant figure to
me. I had the impression that

123.16.text:
he never even knew who I was
even though I'd covered all

126.09.text:
his news conferences and
followed him as a

129.36.text:
presidential candidate.
Then on his last day he was

132.13.text:
speaking at a school in the
city, an elementary school,

135.47.text:
and I was standing at the stage,
just standing there with my

138.57.text:
microphone through this whole,
his little farewell speech

141.64.text:
to the city and suddenly
he just approached me, came over

145.78.text:
and I didn't really know it
was happening, I just smiled at

148.28.text:
him and then suddenly, smack,
that, that big smack-a-roo.

154.35.text:
And that was it. You know I
never said anything to

159.03.text:
>>>TONY GUIDA: Your
reaction? Were you startled?

162.43.text:
>>>IRENE CORNELL: I was
both. He's a very handsome guy.

166.00.text:
I was startled and flattered
and thought, Oh, what was that

169.77.text:
about? And that was the last
time I ever saw John Lindsay.

174.07.text:
>>>TONY GUIDA: And what
was it about? Did anybody,

176.08.text:
did Lindsay's staff ever
say anything to you?

180.11.text:
>>>IRENE CORNELL: He never
said a word. His staff never

182.68.text:
said a word. This was a
room full of reporters and

184.99.text:
photographers. No one said
anything. And I kind of forgot

190.66.text:
about it until these
photos arrived in the mail.

193.66.text:
They were taken by a
Daily News photographer who just

196.10.text:
quietly sent them to me.
And I thought, Whoa.

202.90.text:
>>>TONY GUIDA: That raises
so many questions, I read,

204.91.text:
a Daily News photographer
took the pictures. It was a

208.51.text:
public event. There were
other reporters in the room.

>>>TONY GUIDA: Nobody ever

214.92.text:
you never said any-

>>>TONY GUIDA: And so a room
full of reporters on an

223.72.text:
important day, the mayor's
last day in office, nobody?

227.96.text:
It never made the papers? There
was never a public word

231.83.text:
about this? How is
this possible?

234.27.text:
>>>IRENE CORNELL: That's
the way it was in the 70's.

236.37.text:
If a reporter ran into J.F.K.

241.21.text:
a hotel staircase, which

244.88.text:
be reported. Now that is
what's so different about

now and the point you

I mean, if that happened

259.73.text:

Nobody said a word except my

278.04.text:

281.82.text:
Danny Meenan, great
New York street reporter.

"Lips that touched Lindsley's

Anybody who listens to

421.86.text:
courts became my life. I

424.39.text:
assignment reporting doing

427.56.text:
fires and water main breaks

431.50.text:

436.00.text:

I mean, you can sit, a lot of

441.24.text:
people don't like to cover

444.91.text:
hours of boredom, interrupted

448.21.text:

452.99.text:
of, you know, very
surprising things.

455.99.text:
It's like being, having a front

460.26.text:
every single day. And so
I've never gotten tired of

464.60.text:
it in all of
these many years.

466.47.text:
>>>TONY GUIDA: What inspired
you to become a reporter?

470.74.text:
>>>IRENE CORNELL: I guess
I grew up in the family of

474.14.text:
reporters and thinking about it.
My dad was a newsman,

477.34.text:
television, radio,
newspapers, the whole bit.

479.35.text:
When he did have a T.V. show
we never had a T.V. at home.

486.82.text:
>>>IRENE CORNELL: Right.
He wouldn't allow it.

489.72.text:
>>>TONY GUIDA:
Kind of an odd rule.

491.73.text:
>>>IRENE CORNELL: Yeah.
He didn't want us watching

494.16.text:
T.V., you know, if I wanted to
see Leave it to Beaver

497.13.text:
I have to go to a neighbors
house. So we'd sit around the

501.43.text:
dining room table at night and

504.34.text:

507.27.text:
I grew up. So it was kind of
implanted at a very early

510.71.text:
age and my uncle was religion

515.62.text:
for 40 years. And then
you know my kids started

521.39.text:

is a very well known and

524.16.text:
respected courtroom artist. Your
dad had a, he was an anchorman

528.70.text:
here in New York
on the old Dumont Network,

534.07.text:
WABD channel 5 for people who

539.57.text:
Left there and went to Savannah
as I understand it.

543.58.text:
>>>IRENE CORNELL: Well Dumont

547.75.text:
in Savannah. He was a news

551.32.text:
WSGA radio. So we spent, well
we were actually in Savannah

559.43.text:
for four years until my dad

564.06.text:
very unpleasant for Savannah
society and Savannah

569.30.text:

worked there.

571.60.text:
It's a very insular place.
Or it was then.

576.61.text:
>>>IRENE CORNELL: Yeah. Well
actually what happened was

578.61.text:
there was a little obituary
notice in the Savannah news

581.88.text:
about Harriet Train Blake who
had been, it said she was

587.52.text:
a suicide, and my dad got a call
from a police source who said,

593.33.text:
Look into this Cam. It was
actually shot gun blast to the

597.96.text:

Cameron Cornell, reported

602.97.text:
that Harriet Train Blake,
who was the daughter of

606.11.text:
the owner of the radio
station and the T.V. station and

609.48.text:
the newspaper in Savannah,
was not actually a suicide

613.08.text:
but it was a homicide. And what
he didn't report was that

618.12.text:
it was her lesbian lover who

622.02.text:
early 50's in Savannah and
anyone who's seen Midnight

625.69.text:
in the Garden of Good and Evil
or read the book would know

629.00.text:
that such homicides are

633.03.text:
So my dad was told, You

636.60.text:
Cornell, that it was a

639.77.text:
My dad says, but I was

643.58.text:
to report the news. So he

646.31.text:
the same story and he was

650.55.text:
by the way. Could not
get a job anywhere.

660.89.text:
>>>TONY GUIDA: Did that
discourage, it obviously

663.76.text:
didn't discourage
you it all from-

666.67.text:
>>>IRENE CORNELL: It was a
lesson in, you know, how

668.67.text:
to stand up for what's

673.41.text:
reporting and my dad was

dark vans and cars every

682.45.text:

was not afraid. And so,

686.65.text:
and he always said, Getting

689.82.text:
ever happened to him and

691.82.text:
>>>TONY GUIDA: There's a
lesson about intimidation

695.50.text:
in that to, how to deal

700.33.text:
to intimidate. I think a

705.77.text:
you told me this, a lesson you

711.38.text:
as it were, reporter to person
to report on, person by the

715.72.text:
name of John Gotti, at one of
his trials that you covered

720.89.text:
there was some intimidation
going on, which sounded

724.62.text:
a little scary to me but

729.13.text:
>>>IRENE CORNELL: Well
this was his fourth and

731.46.text:
final trial and at one point

739.61.text:
John Gotti and this was the

743.91.text:
especially a young female

748.01.text:
John Gotti ordered the

750.78.text:
who was also a mobster,

754.99.text:
great courage and I

758.49.text:

762.76.text:
next day I'm in court taking

766.07.text:
says to me, One of

768.60.text:
I said, OK. And I kept taking my
notes.

773.67.text:
>>>IRENE CORNELL: So then
I was out in the phone

776.81.text:
booth, we had those then,

780.65.text:
there's a rap on the phone

who was one

He would consider himself

And he said to me, My friend

800.53.text:
John Miller? Because as

809.61.text:
>>>TONY GUIDA: John Miller

811.78.text:
a great police reporter in this

819.29.text:
>>>IRENE CORNELL: Right.
So anyway, that was kind

821.29.text:
of an aside but anyway, he
said, No. John Gotti,

825.99.text:
my best friend in the world,
John Gotti, doesn't like what

829.13.text:
you said on the radio. So I'm

836.50.text:

840.31.text:
So I said to Mr. Kasman,
Well what does, what was it that

he doesn't like that
you said the woman,

862.90.text:
he doesn't know her, he

865.90.text:
and it would be
wrong to look at her.

872.71.text:
the proper Don. So I said to
Kasman, well you tell Mr. Gotti

880.41.text:
that I'll correct that.
So the way I corrected it was

883.92.text:
to go on every half hour, all
day long, repeating my version

888.99.text:
and then telling the audience
what Mr. Gotti didn't like

892.93.text:
and why. So that way I figured

896.90.text: of the Mafia away from my home.

910.48.text:
It scares me just to hear

finally got sentenced
there was a moment,

921.99.text:

and the judge was

926.26.text:
I. Leo Glasser who didn't care

929.16.text:
So when the jury came in with

933.20.text:
when the press was all

935.70.text:
we called the bad guy

938.10.text:
he decided to take the

942.41.text:

945.31.text:

947.61.text:

975.78.text:

1026.69.text:

What stands out from that trial?

What do you recall

that was another sign of

1044.78.text:
the times trial. She was

1048.81.text:
the attractive red haired

1051.82.text:

1072.07.text:
you know, it turned out

1074.07.text:

1076.88.text:
this was a moment, I mean,
on the way to look at her

1079.48.text:
dead child so the cops

1083.68.text:
after her and she's a

1090.12.text:

1097.86.text:

it was a sideshow, it was a

1108.34.text:
this what we might call

1113.58.text:
>>>TONY GUIDA: -And did

1116.58.text:

1121.59.text:
you know, there was a bit of,
you know, a woman can't live

1125.46.text:
like this. They just
thought that she was a

1127.59.text:

people would say a woman

1130.73.text:
like that. There was a

1160.26.text:

1188.89.text:

their children anyway especially

1196.10.text:

1198.86.text:

1240.67.text:
